docs.lead_paragraph: A mother-to-be found that the Department of Health and Human Services could not give her a free copy of ''Infant Care,'' a book that the agency has distributed without charge for 58 years. A professor of securities law at Columbia University discovered that he could no longer receive free copies of the S.E.C. News Digest, a daily listing of the activities of the Securities and Exchange Commission that is essential to his work. Instead, he was told that he could subscribe to the publication through a private printing operation for $150 a year. And subscribers to the Federal Register, a daily compendium of Government rulings and regulations, have been told that the price of a subscription is now $300 a year, up from $75. In addition, Dial-A-Reg, a telephone service providing the highlights of the next day's issue, has been disconnected.
docs.snippet: A mother-to-be found that the Department of Health and Human Services could not give her a free copy of ''Infant Care,'' a book that the agency has distributed without charge for 58 years.   A professor of securities law at Columbia University...

byline.original: By ANN CRITTENDEN, Special to the New York Times
